title: 106_s526
content: The "Public School Construction Partnership Act" may be cited as the short title. Qualified public educational facility bonds are treated as exempt facility bonds. The "Public School Construction Partnership Act" establishes qualified public educational facilities as exempt facility bonds. Qualified public educational facilities are defined as school facilities owned by a private, for-profit corporation. The Public School Construction Partnership Act defines qualified public educational facilities as school facilities owned by a private, for-profit corporation through a public-private partnership agreement with a State or local educational agency. The agreement involves the corporation constructing, rehabilitating, or equipping a school facility and transferring it to the agency at the end of the term without additional cost. The term "school facility" includes school buildings, related facilities, land, and properties used for educational purposes. Elementary and secondary schools are defined according to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 defines elementary and secondary schools. An issue will not be considered as described in subsection (a)(13) if the total face amount of bonds issued by the State exceeds a certain limit based on population or a set amount. The State may allocate a specified amount in a calendar year as determined appropriate. Rules for carryforward of unused amounts can be elected, with the sole purpose being the issuance of exempt facility bonds. Additionally, there is an exemption from general state volume caps for certain bonds under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include exemptions for environmental enhancements of hydroelectric generating facilities and qualified public educational facilities. Additionally, there is an exemption from the limitation on land acquisition for certain bonds, specifically exempt facility bonds for qualified public-private schools. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include exemptions for environmental enhancements of hydroelectric generating facilities and qualified public educational facilities. A conforming amendment changes the heading of section 147(h) to "Certain Bonds". The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 1999. SEC. 3. Additional increase in arbitrage rebate exception for governmental bonds used to finance education facilities. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a 4-year spending requirement for public school construction issues, where at least 10 percent of the construction proceeds must be spent for governmental purposes within a 1-year period. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a 4-year spending requirement for public school construction issues. Within the 1-year period, 30 percent of the proceeds must be spent for such purposes, increasing to 50 percent within 2 years, and reaching 100 percent within 4 years. The term `public school construction issue' refers to any construction issue where no bond is a private activity bond and all construction proceeds are used for public school facilities for education below postsecondary level or related land acquisition. Other rules apply. The amendment increases the arbitrage rebate exception for governmental bonds used to finance education facilities from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000. This change applies to obligations issued after December 31, 1999. SEC. 4. Public school construction bonds treated as qualified tax-exempt obligations. Public school construction bonds issued after August 7, 1986, by a qualified small issuer and not classified as private activity bonds are considered qualified tax-exempt obligations. Construction bond issued by a qualified small education bond issuer is defined as a qualified tax-exempt obligation. The amendments made by this section limit school construction bonds issued by a qualified small education bond issuer to $25,000,000 per calendar year. The effective date for these changes is after December 31, 1999.
